0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-media-idUSKCN11D1UG	Trump campaign reverses ban on credentials for some media outlets	"
PHILADELPHIA U.S. Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on Wednesday  ended his ban on press credentials for some news outlets seeking to cover his campaign events
column2: including The Washington Post and Buzzfeed
column3: a policy that had drawn strong criticism from press freedom advocates.Trump's ban at times also included Politico and The Huffington Post
column4: following coverage that was critical of him. The banned organizations had continued covering his campaign
column5: but they could not get credentials to formally attend his events
column6: including sitting in the media section at rallies. Those outlets now will be able to obtain media credentials
column7: as well as travel with other reporters covering the Republican candidate
column8: campaign spokesman Hope Hicks confirmed.Press freedom advocates strongly condemned such bans. Reporters without Borders said when the Post was banned in June that it was an ""act of hostility"" toward the media and a serious violation of press freedom.""Revoking press credentials was imprudent
column9: pointless and offensive from the start. We're pleased to see the ban come to a long-overdue end
column10: Washington Post Executive Editor Marty Baron said in a statement on Wednesday.

column1: Sam Stein
column2: senior politics editor for the Huffington Post
column3: said on Twitter the outlet was no longer blacklisted. ""They even returned my email to confirm it
column4: he said of the Trump campaign.Reporters from the banned organizations had often gained access to Trump campaign events by waiting in the same lines as the general public
column5: but they could be tossed out by members of his security team if discovered.

column1: Trump's vice presidential running mate
column2: Indiana Governor Mike Pence
column3: said last month that the campaign was discussing reversing the ban
column4: but no change had been announced before Wednesday.""I figure they can't treat me any worse
column5: Trump
column7: told CNN in a statement declaring the ban over.

column1: Trump is running against Democrat Hillary Clinton for the Nov. 8 election. (Reporting by Steve Holland and Emily Stephenson; Editing by Frances Kerry and Jonathan Oatis)"
1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-commander-idUSKCN11D12K	Trump in TV event with Clinton
column2: says Putin better leader than Obama	"

column1: By Steve Holland and Jeff Mason
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Donald Trump declared on Wednesday that Russia's Vladimir Putin had been a better leader than U.S. President Barack Obama
column2: as the Republican presidential nominee used a televised forum to argue he was best equipped to reassert America's global leadership. Trump suggested at the event in which he and Democratic rival Hillary Clinton made back-to-back appearances that U.S. generals had been stymied by the policies of Obama and Clinton
column3: who served as the Democratic president's first secretary of state.""I think under the leadership of Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton the generals have been reduced to rubble. They have been reduced to a point that's embarrassing for our country
column4: Trump said at NBC's ""Commander-in-Chief"" forum in New York attended by military veterans. It was the first time Trump and Clinton had squared off on the same stage since accepting their parties' presidential nominations in July for the Nov. 8 election.Clinton was grilled over her handling of classified information while using a private email server during her tenure at the State Department. FBI Director James Comey had declared her ""extremely careless"" in her handling of sensitive material but did not recommend charges against her.""I did exactly what I should have done and I take it very seriously
column5: always have
column7: she said.Trump's praise of Putin and his suggestion that the United States and Russia form an alliance to defeat Islamic State militants could raise eyebrows among foreign policy experts who feel Moscow is interfering with efforts to stem the Syrian civil war.""If he says great things about me
column8: I'm going to say great things about him
column9: Trump said of the Russian president. ""Certainly in that system
column11: far more than our president has been.""Trump had called Obama ""the founder of ISIS
column13: in stump speeches several weeks ago. The statement drew broad criticism
column14: prompting him to take a more disciplined approach to campaigning. He has since picked up ground on Clinton in national opinion polls.Trump also flirted with revealing what he had been learning in classified intelligence briefings given to him by U.S. officials because he is the Republican nominee.""There was one thing that shocked me
column15: Trump said. ""What I did learn is that our leadership
column17: did not follow what our experts ... said to do
column19: very surprised. ...Our leaders were not following what they recommended.""Earlier on Wednesday
column20: Trump pledged to launch a new U.S. military buildup
column21: saying America was under threat like never before from foes like Islamist extremists

column1: DEBATE PREVIEW?

The event offered a prelude to how Clinton and Trump will deal with questions on national security issues in their three upcoming presidential debates later in September and in October.Clinton began the forum saying her long experience in government as a U.S. senator and secretary of state made her uniquely qualified to serve as president.She said she had ""an absolute rock steadiness"" to be able to make tough decisions
column2: a not so subtle dig at Trump
column3: who Democrats say is temperamentally unfit for the White House.

column1: Moderator Matt Lauer doggedly pressed her about her handling of emails from a private server while secretary of state from 2009 to 2013. The issue has raised questions about whether she can be trusted to serve as president.Clinton said none of the emails she sent or received were marked top secret
column2: secret or classified
column3: the usual way such material is identified. Appearing in the second half of the hour-long show
column4: Trump faced questions about his fitness for office. Asked if he would be prepared on Day One to be commander in chief
column5: Trump said: ""One hundred percent.""Trump quickly abandoned Lauer's entreaties to avoid attacking his opponent and focus on what he would do if elected president in November.""She's been there for 30 years
column7: and we need it fast."" The event brought together the meticulously prepared Clinton
column9: the wife of former President Bill Clinton
column12: a New York businessman whose brash
column13: freewheeling style has allowed him to dominate the headlines during his campaign.

column1: Clinton said she regretted her decision as a U.S. senator from New York to vote in favor of the much-criticized 2003 Iraq war and that Trump had been in favor of it as well. Trump has condemned the war during his campaign and said he would avoid lengthy conflicts in the Middle East.On the U.S. intervention in Libya in 2011
column2: Clinton rejected Trump's criticism of her support for the effort as secretary of state.""Permitting there to be an ongoing civil war in Libya would be as threatening and as dangerous as what we are seeing in Syria
column3: she said.Trump said Clinton's handling of Libya proved disastrous. Republicans have made much of the fact that the U.S. ambassador to Libya
column4: Chris Stevens
column5: was killed in an Islamist attack in Benghazi
column7: in 2012.""She made a terrible mistake in Libya
column8: said Trump.Clinton said U.S. policies under her leadership at the State Department had helped promote security.""We made the world safer
column9: she said. (Additional reporting by Amanda Becker and Alana Wise in Washington and Gina Cherelus and Jonathan Allen in New York; Editing by Alistair Bell and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-laos-obama-duterte-idUSKCN11E1PV	Duterte tells regional leaders
column2: U.S. not to lecture Philippines on rights	"

column1: By Manuel Mogato
| VIENTIANE
VIENTIANE Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte on Thursday defended his country's human rights record at a regional summit in Laos
column2: urging East Asian leaders and the United States to help Manila eradicate the scourge of illicit drugs.Duterte swept to power in May on promises to wipe out crime and corruption within six months
column3: pledging to wage a war on drug dealers and crush widespread addiction in a country of 100 million.The toll in his government's two-month war on drugs reached 2
column4: 400 last week
column5: with police saying about 900 people died in police operations
column6: and the rest were ""deaths under investigation""
column7: a term human rights activists call a euphemism for vigilante and extrajudicial killings.Setting aside a prepared speech
column8: Duterte spoke for more than five minutes about human rights and his campaign against drugs during the East Asian Summit in the Laotian capital of Vientiane
column9: according to one Indonesian diplomat at the meeting.

column1: Let me tell you about human rights
column2: the diplomat quoted Duterte as saying while displaying a picture of Filipinos killed by American soldiers about a century ago.""This is my ancestors being killed
column3: so why now we are talking about human rights? We have to talk of the full spectrum of human rights.""

column1: Duterte spoke after Obama had delivered a speech that referred to human rights.   Duterte's drive has won popular support at home but the killings have drawn expressions of concern from the United States
column2: a close Philippine ally
column3: and the United Nations.

column1: In a tirade before the Laos summit
column2: Duterte insulted U.S. President Barack Obama and the White House responded by cancelling a two-way meeting.Philippine officials this week handed out a 38-page pamphlet at the summit that praised Duterte's drug campaign. (Reporting by Manny Mogato; Editing by Amy Sawitta Lefevre and Clarence Fernandez)"

5	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-congress-idUSKCN11D2Q9	U.S. lawmakers seek compromise on Zika virus funding	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. lawmakers sought on Wednesday to break a logjam over $1.1 billion in funding to combat the Zika virus
column2: with the Senate possibly considering legislation as soon as next week
column3: even as one congressman toted a jar full of mosquitoes to the House floor to condemn congressional inaction.""Can you imagine the fears and anxieties if the mosquitoes were not in this jar?"" Florida Republican David Jolly told his colleagues as he brandished the container holding about 100 of the insects in the House of Representatives chamber.""Members of Congress would run down the hall to the physician's office to be tested
column4: added Jolly
column5: whose state is the first in the nation with local transmission of the mosquito-borne virus that has spread through the Americas.The potential Senate Zika measure could advance as part of a broader legislative effort to temporarily keep federal agencies operating in the 2017 fiscal year that begins Oct. 1.Republicans and Democrats huddled separately in closed meetings in both the Senate and House to see if they could reach a compromise during a 19-day work session this month
column6: before lawmakers break for a recess in the weeks before the Nov. 8 U.S. election. Lawmakers returned to work this week after a seven-week summer recess.Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell told reporters he was in talks with Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid.

column1: We're looking for a way forward. And I'm hopeful and optimistic that we'll be able to do that
column2: McConnell
column3: a Republican
column4: said of both a temporary agency funding bill and Zika money.In February
column5: President Barack Obama asked Congress to approve $1.9 billion in emergency funds to deal with the Zika virus
column6: which can cause severe birth defects when pregnant women become infected.Since then
column7: both parties have backed $1.1 billion as the funding figure. But fights over side issues related to abortion and Obama's signature healthcare law have bitterly divided the two parties.

column1: One of the biggest controversies involves Democrats' opposition to language
column2: backed by Republicans
column3: that they say would prevent Zika funds for abortion providers like Planned Parenthood
column4: mainly in Puerto Rico.The Miami Herald on Tuesday quoted Senators Marco Rubio of Florida and Senator Roy Blunt of Missouri
column5: who chairs a Senate panel overseeing healthcare funding
column6: suggesting the Planned Parenthood language might have to be dropped in order to reach a deal.Aides to both senators declined to confirm or deny the accuracy of the quotes.

column1: Republican Senator Susan Collins of Maine
column2: asked by Reuters whether she thought Planned Parenthood funding restrictions should be eliminated from Zika legislation
column3: said: ""That would be my preference.""Still
column4: some Republicans were resisting a deal that would abandon the Planned Parenthood language in the Zika bill. (Reporting by Richard Cowan and Susan Cornwell; Editing by Will Dunham)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-ginsburg-idUSKCN11D2U9	Justice Ginsburg hopes 'cooler heads' prevail on high court vacancy	"
By Lawrence Hurley
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said on Wednesday she hoped ""cooler heads will prevail"" over the vacancy on the Supreme Court
column2: suggesting that Republicans should act on President Barack Obama's nominee.Ginsburg's comments at Georgetown Law Center came a day after Democrats in the Republican-controlled Senate renewed their push for a confirmation hearing for Obama's pick
column3: appeals court judge Merrick Garland. The nomination has been pending for 175 days without Senate action
column4: the longest ever to the high court. Republicans have said the next president should get to make the appointment because the vacancy
column5: created by the death of conservative Justice Antonin Scalia in February
column6: came in the final year of Obama's presidency.

column1: I do think that cooler heads will prevail
column2: I hope sooner rather than later
column3: Ginsburg said.Ginsburg
column5: a liberal appointed by Democratic President Bill Clinton in 1993
column7: which has the responsibility to confirm or reject judicial nominations
column8: did not have to confirm the nominee. But she said it did have an obligation to at least consider Garland instead of taking no action at all.

column1: The president is elected for four years
column2: not three years
column3: she said in relation to the president's authority to make appointments in the final year of a term. ""Maybe some members of the Senate will wake up and appreciate that that's how it should be.""Earlier on Wednesday
column4: Democratic senators held a press conference outside the Supreme Court demanding action on the nomination.

column1: But Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has so far held firm to his pledge to take no action.The nine-seat court has been one justice short since Scalia's death. With four liberals and four conservatives now on the bench
column2: an appointment by a Democratic president could end decades of conservative domination on the court.Ginsburg has a long track record of making sometimes outspoken public remarks
column3: in stark contrast to most of her colleagues. In July
column4: she issued a statement in which she said she regretted comments she made in press interviews criticizing Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump. In one CNN interview she described him as a ""faker."""

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-trump-peru-cenbank-idUSKCN11E001	Peru's central bank chief says Trump gives him 'goose bumps'	"

LIMA The head of Peru's central bank said on Wednesday he gets the goose bumps when he thinks about what would happen to the global economy if U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump wins the November election.Responding to questions from reporters on the sidelines of an economic forum
column2: Julio Velarde called Trump's statements about scrapping trade deals and imposing tariffs on Chinese and Mexican imports ""very dangerous.""""If the man does a fraction of what he says he will
column3: we could go back to the '30s
column4: Velarde said in reference to the Great Depression of the early 1930s. ""It gives me the goose bumps.""The comments were videotaped and posted online by local financial daily Gestion.The Trump campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

column1: The New York businessman has broken with the Republican Party's traditional embrace of free trade. He has vowed to rip up the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal to which Peru is a signatory
column2: and renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico that he blames for the loss of U.S. jobs.Trump has also threatened to slap tariffs on Chinese products to show Beijing that Washington is serious about leveling the field on trade.

column1: Velarde
column2: named central banker of the year in 2015 by the Financial Times magazine The Banker
column3: has headed Peru's central bank since 2006 and recently agreed to stay on for a third five-year term.Peru's new president
column4: Pedro Pablo Kuczynski
column5: has also voiced worries about a Trump presidency.

column1: (Reporting by Mitra Taj; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-irs-koskinen-idUSKCN11D1WC	U.S. House Republicans to discuss whether to impeach IRS chief	"
WASHINGTON Members of the Republican majority in the U.S. House of Representatives will discuss next week whether the nation's top tax collector
column2: John Koskinen
column3: should be impeached over conservative charges he stonewalled a congressional investigation
column4: House leaders said Wednesday.Democrats decried the move as a politically motivated embarrassment that would in any case be stopped in the Senate. Even some Republicans said they did not think Koskinen's activities justified impeachment from his post as Internal Revenue Service (IRS) commissioner.Conservative Republicans in the House have said Koskinen failed to comply with a congressional investigation into whether the IRS applied extra scrutiny to applications for tax exempt status by conservative groups between 2010 and 2012.House Speaker Paul Ryan and other leading House Republicans have shown little interest in pursuing impeachment. But Ryan indicated Wednesday that he expected floor action because conservatives had filed a privileged resolution
column5: which can bypass regular procedures and take precedence on the House floor.""This is something that we're going to have a planning conference on next week

column1: I know Koskinen very well

column3: Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch told Reuters. ""Yeah
column4: he's made mistakes but he hasn't made mistakes that justify an impeachment.""Koskinen became IRS commissioner in December 2013
column5: after the controversy already had exploded over the way the agency had handled the applications for tax exempt status.

column1: Members of the House Freedom Caucus
column2: the chamber's most conservative bloc
column3: have said Koskinen should be pushed out because of his role in the aftermath of the scandal. They noted that he was commissioner when backup tapes were destroyed containing emails from former IRS official Lois Lerner
column4: who had headed the IRS' tax-exempt division.Democrats have noted that the Justice Department brought no criminal charges against Lerner and say the case against Koskinen shows little more than agency mismanagement and misstatements. (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Editing by Steve Orlofsky and David Gregorio)"

column2: England U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter on Wednesday warned Russia against interfering with Western ""democratic processes"" and accused Moscow of aggressive behaviour aimed at eroding the international order.
